Higher alcohol synthesis from syngas over xerogel-derived Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalyst with an enhanced metal proximity Seung Ju Han a ⁎ Gyungah Park a Yun-Jo Lee a Ki-Won Jun a b Seok Ki Kim a b Yong Tae Kim a b Geunjae Kwak a b ⁎ a Carbon Resources Institute, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, Daejeon, 34114, Republic of Korea Carbon Resources Institute Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology Daejeon 34114 Republic of Korea b Advanced Materials and Chemical Engineering, University of Science & Technology, Daejeon, 34113, Republic of Korea Advanced Materials and Chemical Engineering University of Science & Technology Daejeon 34113 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Carbon Resources Institute, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, Daejeon, 34114, Republic of Korea. Carbon Resources Institute Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology Daejeon 34114 Republic of Korea Graphical abstract To improve metal proximity of Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalyst, xerogel-derived mesoporous Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalysts (CoCuAl-Xe) with various Co:Cu molar ratios (3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3) were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol-gel method and applied to higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. The CoCuAl-Xe catalyst induced the formation of a composite spinel structure containing Co, Cu, and Al. At the optimal Co/Cu ratio, the Cu atoms efficiently substituted the Co2+ ions in Co3O4 to form the CuCo2O4 spinel structure. However, an excess amount of Cu induced segregation of CuO, leading to decreasing Co-Cu proximity. In higher alcohol synthesis from syngas, all the catalysts showed the linear quasi-Anderson Schulz Flory plot of carbon-containing products, which was attributed to the CO insertion mechanism in higher alcohol synthesis. Among the xerogel catalysts, 2Co1CuAl-Xe exhibited the highest CO conversion and higher alcohol yield. The Co-rich CoCuAl-Xe catalyst was disadvantageous in terms of alcohol selectivity because of a lack of CO insertion sites, and the Cu-rich one was disadvantageous in CO dissociation and led to methanol formation. The computational study suggests that high Co-Cu proximity favors CHOH* mechanism for CH* formation and promotes CO insertion reaction. Consequently, it was found that the optimal Co/Cu ratio and high Co-Cu proximity is required for high catalytic activity in higher alcohol synthesis. Keywords Higher alcohol synthesis Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalyst Xerogel catalyst Co-Cu proximity 1 Introduction Higher alcohol has attracted considerable attention because of its applicability as a fuel additive, hydrogen carrier, and resource for value-added chemicals [1,2]. As most of the supply of higher alcohol is currently based on sugar fermentation or alkene hydration process, diversification of resources for higher alcohol synthesis is needed to meet the future demand [3]. As a higher alcohol resource, syngas was considered favorably because of its high applicability. Also, because syngas can be produced from methane by reforming and partial oxidation process [4,5], higher alcohol synthesis from syngas is a promising technology that is also sustainable and environment-friendly. For the direct conversion of syngas to higher alcohol, catalyst systems that combine the CC coupling and CO hydrogenation reactions have been proposed. The catalyst system for higher alcohol synthesis can be classified into Rh- [6,7] and Mo-based [8–10] catalysts, modified methanol synthesis catalyst [11], and modified Fischer-Tropsch catalyst [3,12–16]. Among them, the modified Fischer-Tropsch catalyst containing Co and Cu as the active phase has been investigated extensively because of its high cost efficiency and high higher alcohol yield [3]. In this catalyst system, CO insertion mechanism is generally accepted; dissociative adsorption of CO occurs on Co sites and non-dissociative adsorption of CO occurs on Cu sites [17]. As the CO insertion mechanism is a combination of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and methanol synthesis, the distribution of hydrocarbon and alcohol obeys Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution [18–20]. Because higher alcohol synthesis requires both reactions to occur simultaneously, the composition and proximity of active metals are crucial for enhancing the catalytic performances [3]. In a recent study [21], the optimal Co/Cu ratio for obtaining higher alcohol yield was found to be 0.35 (Cu/Co ≈ 0.5) with a maximum occurrence of the CoCu alloy phase. However, phase segregation of Cu was unavoidable in the optimal Co-Cu composition because Co and Cu have low miscibility (maximum Cu solubility in Co is 9%) [22]. Furthermore, Cu tends to segregate on the surface during the reaction because of its low surface energy [23]. Therefore, many attempts have been made to increase Co-Cu proximity in an optimal Co-Cu composition. As it is known that cobalt and copper form alloys in the nanoscale, size-controlled Co-Cu alloy nanoparticles have been prepared and applied to higher alcohol synthesis from syngas [24,25]. However, the synthesis of alloy nanoparticles is difficult for obtaining high load metal catalysts and requires the removal of surfactants because the catalytically active sites may be encapsulated and blocked by the surfactant [26]. In the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst, mesoporosity of the catalyst enhances metal dispersion by high surface area and confinement effect [27]. In this regard, a mesoporous carbon supported Co-Cu catalyst has been applied to higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. This catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity because of its improved metal dispersion [28]. In order to achieve a uniformly distributed Co-Cu alloy at high loading, mixed Co-Cu oxide precursor with a specific structure has been suggested. Wang et al. prepared a Cu-Co alloy nanocatalyst derived from layered double hydroxide (LDH) structure ([M1-x 2+Mx 3+(OH)2]x+(An−)x/n.mH2O), which showed high selectivity to C2+ alcohols in higher alcohol synthesis from syngas [29]. Carbon nanotube (CNT) supported Cu-Co LDH was also suggested as a precursor of Co-Cu alloy catalyst. It was demonstrated that the formation of uniformly mixed CuCo2O4 in the LDH structure was favorable for the formation of the Co-Cu alloy catalyst [30]. Tien-Thao et al. prepared LaCo1-xCuxO3- δ perovskites as precursors and investigated the effect of alkali additives on the perovskite-derived Co-Cu catalyst [31,32]. The citric acid sol-gel method was also shown to be an effective mean to prepare a uniformly mixed CuCo2O4 phase, which exhibited high catalytic activity in higher alcohol synthesis from syngas [33]. Since the formation of structure-derived mixed oxides with high dispersion is required for an efficient Co-Cu catalyst, the introduction of mesoporous xerogel structure is expected to enhance the catalytic activity in higher alcohol synthesis. In this work, xerogel-derived Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol-gel method and their promising catalytic activity was applied to higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. Various characterizations and computational study were performed to elucidate the effect of Co/Cu molar ratio and metal proximity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of mesoporous Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalysts Mesoporous Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalysts with various Co/Cu atomic ratios were prepared by the epoxide-driven sol-gel method. Because the Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalyst derived from the LDH structure with the (Co + Cu)/Al molar ratio of 2 exhibited high activity in higher alcohol synthesis [29,30], the same atomic ratio of (Co + Cu)/Al was used in this study. Appropriate amounts of cobalt (cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, Samchun, 97.0%), copper (copper nitrate hydrate, Samchun, 77.0–80.0%), and aluminum (aluminum nitrate nonahydrate, Samchun, 98.0%) precursors were dissolved in ethanol (Samchun, 99.9%) by vigorous stirring. The (Co + Cu)/Al molar ratio was fixed at 2 and the ethanol/total metal precursor molar ratio was fixed at 30. After obtaining a transparent solution, propylene oxide was added for gelation. This led to the condensation of hydrolyzed metal ions and eventually, the Co-Cu-Al2O3 composite gel was obtained. The obtained gel was aged at room temperature overnight and dried at 80 °C. It was then calcined at 400 °C with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min for 5 h under ambient conditions. The prepared Co-Cu-Al2O3 xerogel catalyst was denoted as xCoyCuAl-Xe catalyst, where x:y represents the molar ratio of Co:Cu in the catalyst. Co-Cu/Al2O3 xerogel catalyst was also prepared by 2 step epoxide-driven sol-gel method. At first, alumina xerogel support was prepared by the epoxide-driven sol-gel method described above and it was denoted as Al2O3-Xe. Then aqueous solutions of cobalt (cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, Samchun, 97.0%) and copper (copper nitrate hydrate, Samchun, 77.0–80.0%) precursors with the (Co + Cu)/Al molar ratio of 2 were added into Al2O3-Xe. After aging and drying process, the resultant was calcined at 400 °C for 5 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min. The prepared Co-Cu/Al2O3 xerogel was denoted as 2Co1Cu/Al-Xe. For comparison, the Co-Cu/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by the co-impregnation method. Commercial gamma-Al2O3 (Puralox, Sasol) was calcined under an air flow at 400 °C for 5 h. Aqueous solutions of the cobalt (cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, Samchun, 97.0%) and copper (copper nitrate hydrate, Samchun, 77.0–80.0%) precursors with the (Co + Cu)/Al molar ratio of 2 were added into gamma-Al2O3. After aging for 2 h, the solution was dried at 110 °C overnight, followed by calcination at 400 °C for 5 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min. The resultant catalyst was denoted as 2Co1Cu/Al. 2.2 Characterization The textural properties of the catalysts were studied by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements at −196 °C using an ASAP 2020 system (Micromeritics). Prior to the measurements, the sample was pretreated under vacuum at 300 °C for 12 h. The surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation and average pore diameter was calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) desorption method. Total pore volume was determined at the relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.99. Crystal structures of the catalysts were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis with Ultima (Rigaku) diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.5418 Å). The XRD patterns were recorded by a scintillation counter detector in the 2θ range of 10-80° under 40 kV/40 mA X-ray conditions. The bulk metal compositions of the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis using iCAP 7400 (Thermo Scientific). Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were conducted to investigate the reducibility of the catalysts. For analysis, 100 mg of the calcined catalyst was loaded and pretreated with He for 1 h at 300 °C. The furnace temperature was then increased to 800 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of 5% H2/He mixed gas (50 mL/min). The hydrogen consumption was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) experiments were performed to investigate the CO adsorption sites of the catalysts. Prior to the analysis, 100 mg of the catalyst was reduced under H2 gas at 400 °C for 4 h. The reduced catalyst was then saturated with CO at room temperature for 30 min. The physisorbed CO was removed by purging the sample with He flow at 100 °C for 1 h. The furnace temperature was increased to 900 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of He. The desorbed CO was detected by TCD. The oxidation states and chemical compositions of the catalysts were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis using AXIS NOVA (Kratos). The obtained XPS peaks were deconvoluted using Shirley background and the Gaussian-Lorentzian peak. The surface atomic compositions were calculated using the relative sensitivity factor (RSF) of each component. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) mapping by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) was conducted to determine the atomic distributions and morphologies of the prepared catalyst. The STEM-EDX mapping images were obtained using FEG S/TEM (Talos F200S) at 200 kV. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was conducted using beamline 8C (Nano XAFS) at the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL). The spectroscopic data was collected in the transmittance mode with an electron energy of 3.0 GeV and a ring current of 70–100 mA. Data calibration was performed using the K-edge energy position of Co foil (7709 eV). The collected X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data were analyzed using the Athena software package [34]. 2.3 Higher alcohol synthesis from syngas Higher alcohol (C2+OH) synthesis from syngas was carried out in a fixed-bed steel reactor with an inner diameter of 7.25 mm. The catalyst (0.4 g) was loaded in the reactor with 2 g of alpha alumina as a diluent. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 400 °C under H2 gas for 4 h. After cooling the reactor to the room temperature, premixed syngas (CO/H2 = 1) containing 7% Ar was used as the feed gas. The reaction was conducted at 250 °C and the gas hourly space velocity (WHSV) was fixed at 1800 mL/gcat⋅h. Gaseous products were analyzed online using YL6100 gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a TCD and a flame ionization detector (FID). H2, CO, CO2, and CH4 were analyzed by TCD fitted with a Carboxene 1000 column and the gaseous C1-C8 hydrocarbons were analyzed by FID fitted with an HP-PLOT Q column under He flow. After reaction for 48 h, the liquid products were collected in a cold trap and analyzed offline by YL6100 gas chromatography (GC) and Shimadzu gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GCMS). The aqueous products were analyzed by GCMS with the Rtx-VMS column and the liquid oil products were analyzed by GC equipped with a FID with HP-1 column and GCMS with Rtx-VMS column. As some C6-C8 hydrocarbons in the liquid oil product can be lost, the amounts of C6-C8 hydrocarbons were corrected using the α value obtained from quasi-Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) plots. Quasi-ASF plots for hydrocarbons and alcohols were obtained according to the following equation (Eq. (1) [35]. CO conversion, selectivity and yield for products were calculated by the following equations (Eqs. (2–4)). (1) ln C m o l % n = n l n α + c o n s t a n t (2) X c o % = F C O , i n - F C O , o u t F C O , i n × 100 (3) S i % = n i × F i F C O , i n - F C O , o u t × 100 (4) Y i % = n i × F i F C O , i n × 100 2.4 Computational details The density functional theory (DFT) calculation was conducted by using the Vienna Ab-Initio Simulation Package (VASP) with the revised Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (rPBE) exchange-correlation functional in the generalized gradient approximation [36–38]. The vdw-DF2 functional was used to consider van der Waals interaction on metal surfaces [39–42]. The kinetic energy cutoff was set to 450 eV. A Monkhorst-Pack k-points mesh grid was set to 4 × 4 × 1 for Brillouin zone sampling. The ideal gas assumption, which takes into account translational and rotational degree of freedom, was used for calculating the Gibbs free energy of gas molecules [43]. While, the harmonic limit, which treats only vibrations harmonically, was used for Gibbs free energy of adsorbents [43]. The slab models for Co-Cu intimate and alloy surfaces are constructed based on 4 × 4 × 3 unit cell with 15 Å of vacuum thickness (Fig. S4). In Co hcp (001) surfaces, 1/2 monolayer (ML) surface Co atoms are substituted by Cu atoms to simulate Co-Cu surfaces. In the intimate structure (Fig. S4(a)), the Cu atoms were isolated from the Co atoms, and the alloy structure (Fig. S4(b)) was simulated as a uniform mixture of the Cu and Co atoms. The electronic energies of gas-phase CO, H2, H2O and adsorbed CO* were corrected by −0.18, +0.09, −0.21 eV, and +0.25 eV to accurately describe the overall reaction energies [44–46]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of catalysts N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out to investigate the textural properties of the catalysts. Fig. 1 (a) compares the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Al2O3 and calcined catalysts; commercial gamma-Al2O3 (Puralox, Sasol) as a support for 2Co1Cu/Al. All the samples displayed type-IV isotherms with H2 type hysteresis, which is indicative of mesoporous structures [47]. It is worth noting that the hysteresis loops of alumina supported catalyst were well maintained in the xerogel catalyst (2Co1CuAl-Xe) compared to the impregnated catalyst (2Co1Cu/Al). This might be because pore blockage of Al2O3 support occurred during the additional impregnation of an active metal in the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst. Fig. 1(b) shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts with various Co:Cu molar ratios (3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3). All the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts exhibited type-IV isotherms with H2 type hysteresis, which indicated mesoporous xerogel structure. The detailed textural properties of the support and calcined catalyst are summarized in Table 1 . Al2O3-Xe had a higher surface area and lower pore volume compared to commercial Al2O3. Interestingly, the decrease in surface area and pore volume was prominent in 2Co1Cu/Al after introducing Co and Cu. On the other hand, Al2O3-Xe and 2Co1CuAl-Xe exhibited similar pore volumes. This was attributed to drastic pore blockage during the co-impregnation of metal precursors in 2Co1Cu/Al, whereas Co and Cu ions were involved in forming a gel structure with Al ion during the sol-gel process in 2Co1CuAl-Xe [48,49]. In addition, all the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts showed similar textural properties. This indicates that homogeneous xerogel structures were formed at various Co/Cu molar ratios because of the similar hydrolysis and condensation rates of Co2+ and Cu2+ [50]. Thus, the epoxide-driven sol-gel method proved to be an efficient way to prepare catalysts with high active metal loading, while maintaining the well-developed mesoporosity. 3.2 Crystalline structure and reducibility of calcined catalysts Fig. 2 (a) shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the calcined catalyst. In the CoCuAl-Xe catalyst with a high cobalt ratio (3Co1CuAl-Xe and 2Co1CuAl-Xe), the peaks for the spinel structure were dominant. On the other hand, sharp peaks for CuO (ICDD PDF Card No. 1-1117) appeared at 2θ = 35.8° and 39.0° in the CoCuAl-Xe catalyst with a high copper ratio (1Co1CuAl-Xe, 1Co2CuAl-Xe, and 1Co3CuAl-Xe). This indicates that segregation of CuO occurred in the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts with excess Cu. In Fig. S5, the detailed peak positions of the spinel structure in the calcined catalysts are compared. Because ionic radius decreases in the order of Co > Al > Cu, the peak positions of the spinel structure shift to higher diffraction angle in the order of Co3O4<CoAl2O4<CuCo2O4. The CoCuAl-Xe catalyst showed composite peaks of spinel structures while the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst exhibited a prominent diffraction peak for Co3O4. This indicates that the xerogel-derived composite structure induced the formation of a composite spinel structure containing Co, Cu, Al. In the 3Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst, peaks for Co3O4 (ICDD PDF Card No. 1-1152, 2θ = 65.2°) and CoAl2O4 (ICDD PDF Card No. 2-1410, 2θ = 65.3°) were observed. With increasing Cu/Co ratio, the peak intensity for CuCo2O4 (ICDD PDF Card No. 1-1155, 2θ = 65.8°) increased and the peak position of the spinel structure shifted to a higher angle. This demonstrates that Co2+ ions in Co3O4 were substituted by Cu2+ to form the CuCo2O4 spinel structure. The crystallite sizes of spinel (Co3O4, CoAl2O4 or CuCo2O4) and CuO were calculated by using the Scherrer equation as summarized in Table 2 . 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst retained relatively high crystallite sizes of spinel and CuO compared to xerogel catalysts. This implies that xerogel-derived Co-Cu-Al mixed oxide is favorable for dispersion of spinel structure. Therefore, it is inferred that aluminum in the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts seems to increase Co dispersion by forming a spinel structure. It was also observed that crystallite size of spinel decreased from 8.4 nm to 7.4 nm with increasing Cu molar ratio. While, 1Co2CuAl-Xe and 1Co3CuAl-Xe catalysts retained large crystallite size of CuO, which is indicative of CuO segregation. The reducibility of the catalysts was determined by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis as presented in Fig. 2(b). As the reduction of cobalt oxide occurs in two steps (Co3+ → Co2+ and Co2+ → Co0) [51], 3Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst exhibited three reduction peaks at low temperatures (<300 °C). The reduction peak at the lowest temperature (153 °C) was attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 and the others were attributed to reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co0 [52]. Considering the XRD results (Fig. S5), the broad reduction peak at high temperature (>300 °C) might be attributed to reduction of CoAl2O4 [53]. Interestingly, the reduction peak position of Cu2+ and Co3+ in 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst overlapped, which implies the formation of CuCo2O4 mixed spinel [28,54]. Because the reduced Cu0 species facilitates the reduction of cobalt species by hydrogen transfer [55], catalysts with low Co/Cu ratio (1Co2CuAl-Xe and 1Co3CuAl-Xe) exhibited reduction peak of CoAl2O4 at low temperature. On the other hand, the reducibility of Cu2+ decreased in 1Co2CuAl-Xe and 1Co3CuAl-Xe catalysts. Based on the XRD results (Fig. 2(a)), this was due to the formation of bulk CuO structures by excess Cu ratio [56,57]. Unlike 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst, 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst exhibited only two reduction peaks; the reduction peak at the lower temperature corresponded to the reduction of Cu2+ and that at higher temperature was corresponded to the reduction of Co3+ and Co2+. The absence of a reduction peak at high temperature (>400 °C) indicates the absence of CoAl2O4 spinel, which is in accordance with the XRD result (Fig. S5). 3.3 STEM-EDX mapping images of calcined catalysts Scanning transmission electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray (STEM-EDX) mapping analyses of calcined 2Co1Cu/Al (Fig. 3 (a)) and 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalysts (Fig. 3(b)) were conducted to investigate their morphology and metal distribution. The individual maps of cobalt, copper, and aluminum are represented. The cobalt species were uniformly distributed in both 2Co1Cu/Al and 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalysts. However, aggregation of Cu was observed only in the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst. The 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst exhibited a uniform distribution of Cu; the high surface area and mesoporosity of the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst induced high metal dispersion, preventing CuO segregation. 3.4 XPS and XAS study of calcined catalysts The oxidation states of cobalt and copper in the calcined catalysts were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 4 ). Fig. 4(a) shows the XPS spectra of the Co 2p3/2 peak of the calcined catalysts. To calculate the Co2+/Co3+ surface ratio, XPS spectra were deconvoluted into peaks for Co3+ (˜ 779.6 eV) and Co2+ (˜ 781.0 eV) [58]. Fig. 4(b) shows the XPS spectra of the Cu 2p3/2 peak, which was deconvoluted into a shake-up peak (˜ 942.0 eV) and a Cu 2p3/2 peak (˜ 934.0 eV) [58]. The surface atomic composition was calculated from each deconvoluted area from XPS spectra and the results are summarized in Table 3 . Although CuCo2O4 was not successfully formed in the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst, a lower surface Co2+/Co3+ atomic ratio was obtained compared to 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst. Considering the XRD results (Fig. 2(a) and Fig. S5), a high Co2+ ratio in 2Co1CuAl-Xe was attributed to CoAl2O4 formation. On the other hand, Co3O4 was predominantly formed in the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst, resulting in a low Co2+ ratio. Among the xerogel catalysts, 2Co1CuAl-Xe had the lowest surface Co2+/Co3+ atomic ratio. As shown in the XRD results (Fig. 2(a) and Fig. S5), it was evident that the Co2+ ion was substituted by Cu2+ and the CuCo2O4 spinel structure was formed. However, the Co2+/Co3+ atomic ratio increased drastically with the increasing Cu ratio in 1Co1CuAl-Xe, 1Co2CuAl-Xe, and 1Co3CuAl-Xe catalyst. Therefore, it was inferred that the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst was optimal for CuCo2O4 formation while excess Cu inhibited CuCo2O4 formation by forming bulk CuO. It was also noted that the surface Cu ratio calculated by XPS was much higher than the bulk Cu ratio because of the high tendency of Cu to move to the surface [23]. Fig. 5 (a) shows the Co K-edge near-edge spectra of the calcined catalysts, obtained by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). Both 2Co1CuAl-Xe and 2Co1Cu/Al catalysts exhibited pre-edge peak of 1 s to 3d transition of Co2+ and a white line similar to Co3O4 [59]. It is noteworthy that the white line position of 2Co1CuAl-Xe and 2Co1Cu/Al catalysts were slightly shifted to higher energy as compared to Co3O4. This implied that the average oxidation state of cobalt was increased by the substitution of Co2+ with Cu2+ forming CuCo2O4 [60,61]. The Fourier-transformed k2-weight Co K-edge EXAFS spectra of calcined catalysts are presented in Fig. 5(b). All catalysts exhibited peaks at 1.50, 2.48, and 3.00 Å. Based on the previous reports [17,61], these peaks were assigned to Co3+/Co2+−O, Co3+−Co3+, and Co3+/Co2+−Co3+ coordination, respectively. The relatively high intensity of the Co3+-Co3+ coordination peak in 2Co1CuAl-Xe and 2Co1Cu/Al catalysts was indicative of Co2+ substitution by Cu2+ forming CuCo2O4. In particular, the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst retained the prominent peak of Co3+-Co3+ coordination, which was in good agreement with the XPS results (Fig. 4). 3.5 XRD and CO-TPD measurements of reduced catalysts The crystalline phase of the reduced catalyst was measured by XRD analysis (Fig. 6 (a)). All the catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks of metallic Cu (ICDD PDF Card No. 1-1241, 2θ = 43.5°, 50.4°) and Co (ICDD PDF Card No. 15-806, 2θ = 44.3°, 51.6°). It was observed that the sharpness of the metallic Cu peak is higher than that of Co peak, indicating that Cu was more prone to aggregation. In particular, 2Co1Cu/Al exhibited sharp diffraction peaks of Co and Cu compared to the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst. This indicates that the high surface area and uniform distribution of metal oxide in the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst was more favorable for metal dispersion. In the XRD patterns of the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts, the intensity of Cu peaks increased drastically with the increasing Cu/Co molar ratio, which was in accordance with the high intensity of XRD peaks for CuO in the calcined catalysts (Fig. 2(a)). This implies that the highly crystalline metallic Cu was derived from segregated CuO in the calcined catalysts. Therefore, it is inferred that the spinel structure-derived Co-rich surface in CoCuAl-Xe prevented Cu segregation during the reduction process. The CO desorption behavior of the reduced catalysts was studied by CO-temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) measurements (Fig. 6(b)). A considerably larger amount of CO was desorbed from the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst compared to 2Co1Cu/Al, which was attributed to its high surface area and high metal dispersion. Based on a previous study [28], the medium and strong CO adsorption sites (>400 °C) are the active sites for higher alcohol synthesis. In the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts, desorption peak intensity at high temperature decreased with increasing Cu/Co molar ratio. This indicates that strong CO adsorption site is mainly attributed to dissociative CO adsorption site on cobalt. The drastic decrease of CO-desorption peak was obtained in 1Co2CuAl-Xe and 1Co3CuAl-Xe catalyst with a higher Cu ratio. Considering the XRD results of the reduced catalysts in Fig. 6(a), this could be explained by the severe segregation of Cu0 that induced low Cu dispersion in the reduced catalyst. In order to estimate the Co-Cu proximity of the reduced catalyst, the concentration of Cu contained in the Co-Cu alloy was calculated using Vegard’s law (Fig. 7 ) [62,63]. Because Co (111) (2θ = 44.3°) and Cu (111) peak (2θ = 43.5°) might be overlapped with the Al2O3 (113) peak (ICDD PDF Card No. 1-1243, 2θ = 43.5°), Co (200) (2θ = 51.6°) and Cu (200) peak (2θ = 50.4°) were considered. In CoCuAl-Xe catalyst, Cu concentration increased with increasing bulk Cu/Co molar ratio. This demonstrates that increase of bulk Cu/Co molar ratio induced Cu segregation from Co-Cu alloy. 2Co1CuAl-Xe showed relatively low Cu concentration compared to 2Co1Cu/Al. This shows that higher Co content forms solid solution with Cu in 2Co1CuAl-Xe, which is indicative of higher Co-Cu proximity. 3.6 STEM-EDX mapping images of reduced catalysts Fig. 8 shows the STEM-EDX mapping images of the reduced 2Co1Cu/Al (Fig. 8(a)) and 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalysts (Fig. 8(b)). The individual maps of cobalt, copper, and aluminum are represented. Similar to the STEM-EDX images of calcined 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst (Fig. 3(a)), the reduced 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst exhibited segregated Cu particles. This indicates that the segregated copper oxide species in 2Co1Cu/Al were converted to isolated Cu particles by reduction, which was in accordance with the XRD results (Fig. 6(a)). On the other hand, a uniform distribution of Co and Cu was observed in the reduced 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst, indicating that the high dispersion of Co and Cu were well-maintained during the reduction process. 3.7 Higher alcohol synthesis from syngas Higher alcohol synthesis from syngas over 2Co1Cu/Al, 2Co1CuAl-Xe, and 2Co1Cu/Al-Xe catalyst was performed at 250 °C, 50 bar. All the catalysts exhibited stable catalytic performances for a 48 h-reaction and the detailed catalytic performance is summarized in Table 4 . It was observed that the CO conversion and selectivities for alcohol and higher alcohol in the case of 2Co1CuAl-Xe were higher than those of 2Co1Cu/Al and 2Co1Cu/Al-Xe. This indicates that the mesoporous structure in 2Co1CuAl-Xe enhanced the dispersion and proximity of Co-Cu, facilitating the CO insertion reaction. The superior activity of 2Co1CuAl-Xe compared to 2Co1Cu/Al-Xe can be explained by the fact that aluminum in 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst participates in formation of spinel structure during gelation process, which increases metal dispersion. In particular, relatively high selectivity of methanol in 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst might be due to the isolated Cu sites. The quasi-ASF plots for alcohol and hydrocarbon are shown in Fig. 9 . The natural log of the carbon molar fraction of the product (Ln(Cmol%/n)) and carbon number (n) showed a linear relationship in both hydrocarbon and alcohol. This demonstrates that higher alcohol was synthesized via a CO insertion mechanism, which is a combination of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) and methanol synthesis mechanism [19]. Chain growth probabilities of alcohol and hydrocarbon were calculated from the slope of the quasi-ASF plot [35]. In the case of the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst, chain growth probability of hydrocarbon (0.452) was higher than that of alcohol (0.365), which was in agreement with the results of previous studies [20,64]. It is generally accepted that an intimate contact site of cobalt and copper is the active site for higher alcohol synthesis [21]. Therefore, the chain growth probability for hydrocarbon at the Co site adjacent to the Cu site would correspond to the chain growth probability for alcohol. As the chain growth probability on an isolated Co site would be higher, chain growth probability for hydrocarbon was higher than that for alcohol. Accordingly, the similarity of chain growth probabilities for hydrocarbon and alcohol represents the proximity of cobalt and copper sites. For the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst, the chain growth probabilities of both hydrocarbon (0.689) and alcohol (0.650) are higher than those in the case of the 2Co1Cu/Al. This is attributed to the large amount of medium and strong CO adsorption sites (Fig. 6(b)) where chain growth reaction occurs. Also, the chain growth probability for hydrocarbon and alcohol of the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst are more similar than those of the 2Co1Cu/Al catalyst. This indicates that the cobalt sites in contact with the copper sites are predominant in the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst instead of isolated cobalt sites. In order to investigate the effect of Co/Cu molar ratio, higher alcohol synthesis from syngas over CoCuAl-Xe catalysts with various Co:Cu molar ratio (3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 1:3) was conducted at 250 °C, 30 bar. All the catalysts exhibited stable catalytic activity for 48 h and the detailed catalytic performances of CoCuAl-Xe catalyst are summarized in Table 5 . In higher alcohol synthesis, CO2, CH4, C2+H, and methanol were produced as byproducts. Comparing the reaction at 250 °C, 50 bar (Table 4), 2Co1CuAl-Xe gave lower yields of higher alcohol at 250 °C, 30 bar. This is because high reaction pressure favors CO insertion into adsorbed CHx species to form alcohol [65,66]. Although it is generally known that CO conversion in Fischer Tropsch synthesis increases with increasing pressure [67], 2Co1CuAl-Xe exhibited higher CO conversion at 250 °C, 30 bar. This might be due to the decrease of bulk diffusivity or reoxidation of cobalt species at higher reaction pressure above optimal point [68,69]. CO conversion of the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts decreased in the order of 2Co1CuAl-Xe (71.9%) >3Co1CuAl-Xe (68.5%) >1Co1CuAl-Xe (54.1%) >1Co2CuAl-Xe (41.6%) >1Co3CuAl-Xe (22.5%). Although Co sites is mainly related to CO conversion, 2Co1CuAl-Xe retained higher CO conversion than 3Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst. This is because efficient Cu2+ insertion in the CuCo2O4 spinel structure occurred in the 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst (Table 3), and this increased the cobalt surface area for CO dissociation. Meanwhile, CO conversion decreased rapidly in the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts with the high Cu ratio (1Co1CuAl-Xe, 1Co2CuAl-Xe, and 1Co3CuAl-Xe) because of a lack of Co sites for CO activation. The selectivity for CO2 also follows the trend of CO conversion. This might be because water formation is accompanied by CO dissociation and CO2 is mainly produced by in the water gas shift reaction (CO + H2O → CO2 + H2). On the other hand, the selectivity toward alcohol increased with the increasing Cu ratio, indicating that non-dissociative adsorption of CO on Cu sites was related to alcohol formation. The rapid increase of methanol selectivity in 1Co2CuAl-Xe and 1Co3CuAl-Xe might be attributed to the increase in the number of isolated Cu sites (Fig. 6). The quasi-ASF plots for hydrocarbon and alcohol over CoCuAl-Xe catalyst are shown in Fig. 10 . The chain growth probabilities (α) of hydrocarbon and alcohol were estimated by the slope of ln(Cmol%/n) for carbon number. Similar to the results of the previous reaction (Fig. 9), chain growth probability of hydrocarbon was higher than that of alcohol over all the catalysts. The 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst exhibited lower chain growth probability of alcohol at 30 bar (0.570) compared to the reaction at 50 bar (0.650), demonstrating that chain growth reaction is more favorable at higher reaction pressures [67]. It was also observed that the chain growth probability of alcohol decreased with increasing copper ratio. This might be because of the reduced number of Co sites for the chain growth reaction. The drastic decrease in the α value for alcohol in the 1Co2CuAl-Xe and 1Co3CuAl-Xe catalysts was indicative of the reduced number of Cu sites adjacent to Co sites because of Cu segregation. 3.8 Computational study To understand the reaction chemistry on Co-Cu surface, DFT calculation was performed. Two surface slab models of CoCu surface (Fig. S4(a) Co-Cu intimate surface and Fig. S4(b) Co-Cu alloy surface) were simulated to investigate the effect of metal proximity. Fig. 11 (a) shows reaction pathway of higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. It includes carbide mechanism with direct dissociation of CO and CHOH* mechanism with CHOH* as the intermediate. According to the literature [17], it is known that the FTS reaction occurs on Co sites in CoCu catalyst. Therefore, the free energy diagram for CH* formation on Co sites with different CoCu structures were compared. Fig. 11(b) shows free energy diagram for CH* formation via direct dissociation at 523 K, 30 bar. The most endergonic step in this pathway was C–O bond dissociation and is more endergonic on Co-Cu alloy surface (ΔG =0.956 eV) than Co-Cu intimate surface (ΔG =0.825 eV). This might be because the Co sites of the Co-Cu alloy surface contacts more Cu atoms, which decreases binding energy of C* and O* on Co. In case of CHOH* mechanism (Fig. 11(c)), CO* hydrogenation to CHO* is the most endergonic step and is much more endergonic on Co-Cu intimate surface (ΔG =1.219 eV) than Co-Cu alloy surface (ΔG =0.733 eV). This means that the Cu addition makes the CH* formation mechanism via CHOH* favorable, which is similar with the DFT study in Fe-Cu alloy surface [70]. Also, this implies the possibility of ethanol formation via CHOH* intermediate mechanism (CHOH* + CH* → CHCHOH*). The effect of metal proximity on chain growth and CO insertion reaction was investigated in Fig. 12 . Fig. 12(a) compares the free energy difference between the chain growth reaction (2CH* → CHCH*) and the CH* hydrogenation reaction (2CH* + 2H* → 2CH2*). It is noteworthy that the Co-Cu intimate surface exhibits broader energy gap (0.79 eV) compared to Co-Cu alloy surface (0.53 eV). This demonstrates that Co-Cu intimate surface with smaller Cu contact is more favorable for chain growth reaction. This result explains why the chain growth probability of alcohol is lower than that of hydrocarbon, demonstrating that the similarity of the chain growth probability can be a measure for metal proximity. Fig. 12(b) shows the free energies of CO insertion reaction on Co-Cu intimate and Co-Cu alloy surfaces. Both CHCO* formation and CHCHOH* formation reactions on Co-Cu alloy surface were calculated to be more exergonic than those on Co-Cu intimate surface. Therefore, it is inferred that high Co-Cu proximity promotes CO insertion reaction, resulting in higher alcohol formation. 4 Conclusion The effect of metal composition and proximity on higher alcohol synthesis from syngas was investigated. Xerogel-derived mesoporous Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalysts (CoCuAl-Xe) with various Co:Cu molar ratios (3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3) were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol-gel method and applied to higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. The XRD results revealed that Cu addition induced the formation of the CuCo2O4 spinel structure and an excess amount of Cu induced the segregation of CuO. XPS results showed that the Co/Cu molar ratio of 2 was optimal for the substitution of Co2+ by Cu2+ in the spinel structure. It was observed that spinel structure-derived Co-rich surface in CoCuAl-Xe favored high metal dispersion and proximity. The linear relationship in the quasi-ASF plot suggested that higher alcohol synthesis was mainly governed by the CO insertion mechanism. Among the CoCuAl-Xe catalysts, 2Co1CuAl-Xe catalyst showed the highest CO conversion and higher alcohol yield. This is because the optimal Co/Cu ratio efficiently formed CuCo2O4 spinel structure and increased cobalt dispersion. Meanwhile, CoCuAl-Xe catalysts with an excess Cu ratio was unfavorable for chain growth reaction, resulting in high methanol selectivity. The computational study revealed that high Co-Cu proximity favors CO hydrogenation via CHOH* mechanism and CO insertion reaction. In conclusion, optimal Co/Cu ratio with high Co-Cu proximity is required for efficient higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. coredata.dc:description: To improve metal proximity of Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalyst, xerogel-derived mesoporous Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalysts (CoCuAl-Xe) with various Co:Cu molar ratios (3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3) were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol-gel method and applied to higher alcohol synthesis from syngas. The CoCuAl-Xe catalyst induced the formation of a composite spinel structure containing Co, Cu, and Al. At the optimal Co/Cu ratio, the Cu atoms efficiently substituted the Co2+ ions in Co3O4 to form the CuCo2O4 spinel structure. However, an excess amount of Cu induced segregation of CuO, leading to decreasing Co-Cu proximity. In higher alcohol synthesis from syngas, all the catalysts showed the linear quasi-Anderson Schulz Flory plot of carbon-containing products, which was attributed to the CO insertion mechanism in higher alcohol synthesis. Among the xerogel catalysts, 2Co1CuAl-Xe exhibited the highest CO conversion and higher alcohol yield. The Co-rich CoCuAl-Xe catalyst was disadvantageous in terms of alcohol selectivity because of a lack of CO insertion sites, and the Cu-rich one was disadvantageous in CO dissociation and led to methanol formation. The computational study suggests that high Co-Cu proximity favors CHOH* mechanism for CH* formation and promotes CO insertion reaction. Consequently, it was found that the optimal Co/Cu ratio and high Co-Cu proximity is required for high catalytic activity in higher alcohol synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Higher alcohol synthesis from syngas over xerogel-derived Co-Cu-Al2O3 catalyst with an enhanced metal proximity
